70 years later it‚Äôs the cell phone camera that has exposed the continuation of violence directed at Black people by the police and exposed the reality that the right of life liberty and the pursuit of happiness is not guarantee to all of us at all times.

News cameras exposed to the world that Black people did not have the same constitutional protections, that freedom of speech, the right to assemble and protest were not rights extended to African Americans.

In the 1950‚Äôs news cameras exposed the brutal horror of legalized racism in the form of segregation. The news cameras of the 1950‚Äôs exposed the brutal treatment of people who dared to challenge the system.
Black communities have been sadly marching for over 100 years against police abuse and for the police to protect and serve our communities like they do elsewhere.

People marching to demand not just change but transformative change that ends police brutality, that ends racial profiling and ends the practice of denying Americans the ability to sue when they have been injured, that denies local jurisdictions the power to fire or prosecute.

The world is witnessing the birth of a new movement in our country. This movement has now spread to many nations around the world, with thousands marching to register their horror at hearing the cry ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt breathe.‚Äù

RT @RepJayapal This legislation is a bold step towards justice and accountability. I'll fight to swiftly move it though Congress.
 
We need everyone across the country to continue building the public pressure necessary to get this approved by the House, passed in the Senate and signed into law.

RT @RepJayapal 8‚É£It works to END the militarization of law enforcement by restricting the program that allows military equipment to transfer to local departments.
 
It also requires federal, state, and local law enforcement to use existing federal funds to ensure the use of police body cameras.

RT @RepJayapal 7‚É£It gives DOJ the power to subpoena law enforcement departments for pattern and practice investigations, which allows them to hold accountable agencies who violate the constitution or other federal laws.
 
It also establishes a National Task Force on Law Enforcement Oversight.

RT @RepJayapal 6‚É£This bill allows prosecutors to hold officers accountable for the deprivation of civil rights AND civil liberties by changing the mens rea requirement from ‚Äúwillful‚Äù to ‚Äúknowingly or with reckless disregard‚Äù.
 
This improves accountability for police brutality and misconduct.

RT @RepJayapal 5‚É£It requires the reporting of ALL incidents of use of force against a civilian to the Justice Department and mandates that demographic data and an explanation of the incident are included too.
 
It also collects data on law enforcement practices such as stops and searches.

RT @RepJayapal 4‚É£It finally ends qualified immunity.
 
This ensures that we are able to hold accountable police officers and members of law enforcement who perpetrate violence, murders, and injustices‚Äîno matter what badge they wear.

We have seen too many lives taken and communities devastated by police brutality and racial profiling. Action is long overdue. @HouseDemocrats are fighting for REAL reform in our country‚Äôs police departments. #JusticeInPolicing http://pbs.twimg.com/amplify_video_thumb/1270034317419393025/img/lapU0fhvUkuGe3VA.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1270034317419393025/vid/320x320/12zMT13H6xI5vIf0.mp4?tag=13

RT @RepJayapal 3‚É£It establishes a federal police misconduct registry that is public and tracks complaints at the local, state, and federal level.
 
This increases accountability and transparency while ensuring past misconduct can be detected when an officer is trying to transfer departments.

RT @RepJayapal 2‚É£It finally classifies lynching as a federal hate crime in the United States. We know that this is long overdue but it is also urgently necessary today as we just witnessed the modern-day lynching of Ahmaud Arbery in Georgia.

RT @RepJayapal 1‚É£It not only bans chokeholds like the one used to murder George Floyd, but it establishes them as a civil rights violation too.
 
It also bans no-knock warrants for drug cases like the one that was used when officers murdered Breonna Taylor, shooting her at least eight times.

It was the same story in Benton‚Ä¶ in Danville‚Ä¶ in Morehead‚Ä¶ all around the Commonwealth and all around the country. Our country has remembered that peace and protest can ‚Äì and must ‚Äì co-exist. (9/9)
In Hazard, a town of about 5,000 people in eastern Kentucky, citizens gathered for what they called a ‚ÄúMarch of Love.‚Äù (8/9)
In southeastern Kentucky, in Corbin, more than a hundred gathered for a peaceful demonstration that included a prayerful moment of silence. The police officers keeping watch joined in. (7/9)
In Henderson, in western Kentucky, two hundred people ‚Äì protesters, law enforcement, and local leaders alike ‚Äì gathered for an interfaith prayer vigil. (6/9)
And while a lot of ink has been spilled recently about our big cities, we cannot miss that this moment is echoing throughout small-town America as well. (5/9)

In Lexington, a moment of silence was held at an historic former slave market. Then a group marched to police headquarters. Police officers including the Chief came out and met them in civil discourse. (4/9)

In my home state of #Kentucky, in Louisville, just like around the nation, hundreds gathered to remember Breonna Taylor on what would have been her 27th birthday and continue to call for answers. (3/9)

But unlike what our nation faced about a week ago, this weekend‚Äôs demonstrations seem to have been almost entirely peaceful. No more rampant looting. No more police precincts set on fire. By and large, just peaceful protests in our great American tradition. (2/9)

Creates a National Police Misconduct Registry to prevent problematic officers who are fired or leave an agency from moving to another jurisdiction without accountability.

Removes barriers to prosecuting police misconduct and recovering damages. Reforms qualified immunity to hold officers accountable who violate a person‚Äôs civil rights.

Makes lynching a federal hate crime.

Bans chokeholds, carotid holds, and no-knock warrants in drug cases at the federal level and incentivizes state and local governments to do the same.

De-militarizes the police by limiting the transfer of military weaponry to state and local police.

Prohibits federal, state, and local law enforcement from racial, religious and discriminatory profiling. Requires training on racial, religious, and discriminatory profiling for all law enforcement.

Increases transparency by requiring dashboard and body cameras.
